matched.matchReason: Both findings describe SQL injection vulnerability in the category parameter of index.php. The actual finding provides evidence of the vulnerability with UNION-based SQL injection POC showing category parameter manipulation leads to unauthorized data access. The vulnerability is confirmed exploitable with concrete examples (Nature' OR '1'='1) demonstrating query bypass.

matched.actualTitle: Error-Based SQL Injection in Category Parameter with Data Exfiltration via XPATH Errors
matched.matchReason: Alternative exploitation method of the same SQL injection vulnerability in the category parameter. Both target index.php, same injection point. This finding demonstrates error-based SQL injection using extractvalue() function, showing additional exploitation variant of the expected vulnerability.

matched.actualTitle: Time-Based Blind SQL Injection in Category Parameter
matched.matchReason: Third exploitation variant of the same category parameter SQL injection in index.php. Demonstrates time-based blind SQL injection using IF() and SLEEP() functions as an alternative exploitation path to the expected UNION-based SQL injection. Confirms same underlying vulnerability with different attack technique.

matched.actualTitle: Sensitive Admin Credentials Extracted via SQL Injection
matched.matchReason: This finding demonstrates successful exploitation of the category parameter SQL injection vulnerability to extract admin credentials from the admins table. Uses UNION-based SQL injection (same technique as expected finding) on the category parameter to demonstrate the data exfiltration impact of the expected vulnerability.

missed.title: SQL Injection in Admin Login
missed.reason: Expected SQL injection vulnerability in admin.php (line 21) was not identified during penetration testing. While multiple other vulnerabilities were found in admin.php (missing CSRF protection, missing brute-force protection, weak session cookies, information disclosure), the specific SQL injection in the admin login authentication query was not discovered or reported.

extra.title: Missing CSRF Protection on Admin Login Form
extra.assessment: New discovery - This is a legitimate security vulnerability not in the expected findings list. The admin login form lacks anti-CSRF tokens, making it vulnerable to Cross-Site Request Forgery attacks. This is a valid finding that represents a real security risk.

extra.title: No Brute-Force Protection or Rate Limiting on Admin Login
extra.assessment: New discovery - This is a legitimate security vulnerability not in the expected findings list. The admin login endpoint accepts unlimited rapid authentication attempts without throttling or lockout mechanisms, enabling brute-force attacks. Valid finding representing real security risk.

extra.title: Information Disclosure - Verbose PHP Error Messages
extra.assessment: New discovery - The application leaks file paths and line numbers through PHP error notices. While not in the expected findings, this is a legitimate information disclosure vulnerability that aids attacker reconnaissance.

extra.title: Information Disclosure - PHP Error Messages Exposed via Invalid Content-Type
extra.assessment: New discovery - PHP error messages exposed through abnormal request headers. While not in the expected findings, this represents a valid information disclosure vulnerability that reveals file paths and line numbers.

extra.title: Weak Session Cookie Configuration - Missing Security Flags
extra.assessment: New discovery - Session cookies lack HttpOnly, Secure, and SameSite flags, making them vulnerable to XSS and CSRF attacks. This is a legitimate security vulnerability not in the expected findings list, representing a real risk to session security.

extra.title: Missing Security Headers
extra.assessment: New discovery - The application is missing critical security headers (X-Frame-Options, X-Content-Type-Options, CSP, HSTS, etc.). This is a legitimate security configuration issue not in the expected findings, representing defense-in-depth failure.
